btw, i"m not sure if your env variables are correct :)

```
------vm environment    intend to setup a persistant couch db------
$ export OW_DB=Cloudant
$ export OW_DB_USERNAME=admin
$ export OW_DB_PASSWORD=password
$ export OW_DB_PROTOCOL=https
$ export OW_DB_HOST=http
$ export OW_DB_PORT=6000
```

LGTM, memo to myself to merge.

you are not using a persistent couch, aren"t you. Just deploy the ephemeral couch.

Pls do it as follows

```
export OW_DB=CouchDB
export OW_DB_USERNAME=admin
export OW_DB_PASSWORD=86889125
export OW_DB_PROTOCOL=http
export OW_DB_HOST=172.17.0.2
export OW_DB_PORT=6000

ansible-playbook -i environments/local setup.yml
```

after that, ensure you have a file called `db_local.ini`  in the ansible folder. Pls compare the credentials there with your credentials that are exported via bash above.

Then

```
ansible-playbook -i environments/local couchdb.yml
ansible-playbook -i environments/local initdb.yml
ansible-playbook -i environments/local openwhisk
```

I change it to 
$ export OW_DB=couchdb
$ export OW_DB_USERNAME=admin
$ export OW_DB_PASSWORD=password
$ export OW_DB_PROTOCOL=https
$ export OW_DB_HOST=http
$ export OW_DB_PORT=5984

the same issue happens,but then I execute installing DB command(couchdb.sh, initDB.sh...) and couchDB can be created successfully.

You have to urlencode your document id. The url should be `http://localhost:5984/root_vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64_whisks/whisk.system%2Fsamples%2Fecho`. The `/` is part of the id, not the URL.

In your first case it'ld be `http://localhost:5984/root_vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64_whisks/guest%2F0401366437f84d90b4a3bc614ed3fc23`
problem solved. Thanks

Issue being the "fatal error" mentioned above? As @lehoanganh mentioned, this is an expected "error" currently and skipped for a reason. You can ignore it for the moment, if you're not using a `docker-machine` based setup.

Fixed by #650

@domdom82 @lehoanganh the tar command used to build the docker black box uses `--transform` which is supported by GNU `tar` but not `bsdtar` which uses `-s` instead. The latter appears to be common to mac users. We need to change the archive approach. Two options: use zip, matching iOS SDK; copy `docker` dir to `dockerSkeleton` in `tmp` dir, tar and delete copied dir.

Rebased, squashed and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/3f50c7b990145cebbd269a5978b7badd84123c5e.

Does `nginx` also provide any protection against uploading large entities?

@psuter I think nginx is already configured to reject too big requests.
But, on only blocking too big requests with nginx, the user can create an action, which is smaller than the nginx limit, and then he would be able to add a lot of annotations or parameters with an update.

The Go CLI binary compression is now moved the Go CLI build scripts into the Go CLI Dockerfile.
The compressed file names are as follows.  The python CLI and Bluemix CLI downloads use the a product/feature label in the download file name (i.e. "openwhisk"); these file names now follow that convention:
Windows:
- `openwhisk-win-386.zip`
- `openwhisk-win-amd64.zip`

Mac: 
- `openwhisk-mac-386.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-mac-amd64.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-mac-arm.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-mac-arm64.tar.gz`

Linux:
- `openwhisk-linux-386.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-amd64.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-arm.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-arm64.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-mips64.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-mips64le.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-ppc64.tar.gz`
- `openwhisk-linux-ppc64le.tar.gz`

I like this approach because it frees us from a _lot_ of runtime concerns. For example, some user needs NodeJS version x.y.z with a laundry list of third party npm modules installed, no problem... Instread of creating a new runtime just for them, we make it easy for them to create their own Docker image, then they get **exactly** what they want, without requiring anything from the OW system directly.

@dubeejw - Ready for another review please.  Thanks!

/cc @csantanapr

Also, running my Go-based image for the first invocation was extremely slow. I assume this was the platform pulling my custom image down from Dockerhub. 

Having an "official" OpenWhisk Docker SDK base image would mean it's kept in the cache and speed up running new Actions.

There has been some discussion of unifying all the built-in runtimes with the same NodeJS server (as opposed to the various copies of Node, Python, and Java servers we have today). This common image could possibly be the base image for all the built-in runtimes as well.
@bjustin-ibm is there a github issue for that? i think this is a great item which shouldn't get lost, also perf-related cc @perryibm

See https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/675#issuecomment-226796231 for current compressed file names.

/cc @houshengbo @johnsolm

> @bjustin-ibm is there a github issue for that?

@mbehrendt I'm not aware of any existing issue. I created #691 to officially track this work.
@perryibm: @mbehrendt suggested this may be of interest to you.

Note that there are performance advantages to write the web server in the same language as the action, since in most languages we can avoid spawning a separate process for each invocation.

I think we currently exploit this for javascript and Java.  Maybe for python also.

In any case, performance trumps code reuse for this -- so it's not a clear win to refactor as proposed in all cases.

Just chiming in to point out that there are some advantages in using a server written in the language: for instance, for Java actions, we'll eventually be able to stream the `jar`s straight from the DB to the classloader.

> Maybe for python also.

Yes.

I recall the goal of the consolidation being different - we currently clone and own each proxy server in the different runtimes. The python proxy is cloned and owned from python action to swift and swift:3. Consolidation at this level (when in fact we are not or may not be using the proxy in the same language as the action) is good. Using nodejs proxy for a Java action was not the goal.
Good points.  However, we currently have 3 runtimes using the python web server, and really only one of them utilizes this performance advantage.

I have reduced the scope of this issue in the title. Though I do remember @markusthoemmes (of all people) suggesting that all action containers should use a NodeJS server. Or perhaps he was joking? :)
Surely he was joking. Surely. 😆
The limits should be read from a configuration file rather than coded directly in scala. This will allow changes without having to rebuild the core.
I would add a trait that defines a size method and mix it with all the types for which you want to enforce a limit.

The Node.js runtimes already share the same code base. This leaves us with duplication in the Swift runtimes, which currently are very similar (but not identical) to the Python one. I think many of us assume that the Swift runtime will eventually be in Swift, once the language and libraries have matured on Linux. In the meantime, there are four options I can think of:
1. build `swiftActionBase` à la `nodejsActionBase`, keep distinct from `pythonAction`.
2. build `pythonBase` and make it flexible enough to accommodate the differences in Swift action containers, then use for Python, Swift, Swift3.
3. make Swift action containers extend from `nodejsActionBase`, making sure it can accommodate it.
4. do nothing until Swift actions can run in Swift entirely.

The way I see it, 1. and 4. seem reasonable, 2. & 3. would introduce temporary workarounds with non-obvious benefits. I may also be missing other de-duplication opportunities.

In the controller, I would try to gate any requirements as early as possible - so possibly not even reaching methods like create. This can potentially be done with a directive to check content payloads for a desired schema and rejecting the route with an appropriate message.
+1 on options 1 and 4. Low priority on either option unless it's somehow making our runtime support better for that language.

it might also be interesting to look into sharing a common docker image/file where then the lang-specific elements can be layered on top. with that, i think we'd only have to pull that common img once and it can be reused. that would also have the benefit of speeding up docker actions. have we looked into that already?
We made sure the images have common stems and layers where possible.
thx -- sounds great @jthomas you had pointed in a different issue to no common image being available. is that maybe a gap we should be closing?

The docker action image was completely broken until https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/ee72ad01b88c9d8fece3d8ce9f1a518afff3663d merged very recently. I'll have to take a look at what he did before I can comment. We don't make that image available on docker hub yet (although we can - currently you download the Dockerfile with `wsk install sdk docker`). This is a separate issue better addressed in #690.

Use your Vagrant machine IP instead which is `192.168.33.13` by default (check your Vagrant file). Also see https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/vagrant/custom#using-cli-from-outside-the-vm-optional.

there are 2 ip ,
IP address for eth0:    10.0.2.15
IP address for docker0: 172.17.0.1
which one?
they are the IPs inside your vagrant. You have to use the IPs in your local dev env.

this is not an issue related to ansible deployment, isn't it. You can use `docker` command directly in your mac instead of using `docker-machine`  command.

```
export DOCKER_HOST="tcp://192.168.99.102:4243
```

Pls ignore the use of `docker-machine env whisk` (`tweak-dockermachine.sh` would tell you which export you should do, instead of `docker-machine env`)

Also note that Swift performance latency is much worse than it should be for warm invocations.   We have not yet ruled out the python web server as the source of the problem.

Someday we should add python and Java to scenario1 testing.

There is a reference to this here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/db#using-couchdb. Adding the above to make it more explicit in the `db` docs is good idea.

This is covered by the ansible couchdb playbook: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/couchdb/tasks/deploy.yml#L31 - not sure if it can be factored to that others can use this for their own couchdb. @lehoanganh thoughts?
My bad I didn't see that in the docs. Sorry.

The easiest way to cope with situation is to add private network into your vagrantfile. You can either configure it as a static IP or DHCP: https://www.vagrantup.com/docs/networking/private_network.html.

To make it easier, I used to add 
config.vm.network "private_network", ip: "192.168.50.4"
into the vagrantfile. Then you can access your vagrant via 192.168.50.4.
Support docker for mac (beta) would also be great.

1. CLI was not removed (and still using the Python CLI by default).
2. Ansible is for deployment. Gradle is for builds.

Suggest you confirm that `wsk` exists in your `openwhisk/bin` directory and provide more steps to reproduce your problem.
You need `zip` on your host machine.

Another data point is that, because Swift is compiled, I don't think it has the same performance advantage as interpreted languages like Python and Node by having the web server written in the same language as the action. I suspect the only way this performance advantage could work for Swift is if the action code and the web server were compiled together, which can't really happen in OW.

Whatever language is used for the Swift runtime's web server, in the end it will essentially need to "shell out" to run the compiled action binary. If a common Docker image with a NodeJS server is created in #690 then I believe the Swift runtimes could potentially make use of that as a starting point.
